dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grounds of a New England manor. Pre-dawn misty.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE MANOR
dialogues.text: Unlit and still. Gothic with a theme of antique games, arcane puzzles and decorative weapons. First floor: A drawing room, living room, kitchen. The detritus of a party. Stray champagne flutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow one housekeeper named FRAN carrying a tray of coff up a flight of stairs. Second floor: a hallway, doors all closed. The house has not woken up, and Fran steps lightly. Up a much narrower creaky flight of steep stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third floor: the master bedroom suite.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: Morning Mr Thrombey But the bed is empty, unslept in. A robe thrown across it Fran heads out onto the landing and UP an EVEN NARROWER h flight of stairs, which leads to a single door. FRAN (cont'd) Mr Thrombey you up there? Mr Thrombey I'm coming in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cramped attic study, every shelf crammed with curios. The door swings open and Fran sees: HARLAN THROMBEY himself. 85 years old. Slung across a white leather day bed. Throat slit. Drenched in blood. Very much dead.  Fran's tray slips out of her hands for a second.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: Shit. CUT TO: Title card, on black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTA CABRERA wakes with a cry. Plain, modern, cramped. Marta, in her late twenties, take a moment to catch her breath. Opens a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny window in a cheap apartment building opens, Marta' face appears breathing deep. SUPER: "ONE WEEK - after Harlan Thrombey's demise"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marta sits in front of a laptop. Her MOM is at the table with her, her sister ALICE watches CSI on an iPad on the counter top. Murder related dialog from the show. Marta scroll through a jobs site, tired, eyes dead. Her m watches, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Alice, turn that off now.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE MOM
dialogues.text: Why it's almost over, what - Now please just turn it off. they're finding out who did it and the wifi sucks in my room so it doesn't play it's like two minutes left what there isn't even anything Turn it off. Now. Alice. Off. bad on it, it's just normal tv and they're just talking ok ok goddddd whatever ok whatever. They're talking about murder on it, your sister just had a friend she loves slit his throat open she doesn't need to be hearing that right now let's be sensitive!  Mom standing yelling, Alice slams the iPad cover closed. Marta puts her head in her hand. Looks at her mom, who looks back at her with protective sympathy. Marta starts laughing at the absurdity of it, but the laugh turns into crying.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Alice you can keep watching your show it's alright.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No, I guessed who did it anyway. I'm sorry Marta. Alice hugs her sister. Marta's phone rings. WALT THROMBEY

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: It's Harlan's son. (answers) Hi, Walt. (listens) Uh huh. Her face shifts in confusion. MARTA (cont'd) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long narrow private road leading to the Thrombey estate Marta's shitty SUBCOMPACT car buzzes by, towards the hous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several cars, including a police cruiser with a few uniformed officers by it. Marta pulls up. An officer eyes her, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Hey! Excuse me ma'am. Are you with the help? MEG, Thrombey's college aged granddaughter, trots out.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Hey! Her name is Marta, she was granddad's nurse, she's with us. "The help?".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the cop) (mutters ) It's ok, sorry. No. It's not ok. What the hell? They hug, and are both instantly crying. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Not very good. Alone, lots of just, this (the crying) and not knowing what to do next.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Anything you need, you're part of this family Marta.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thrombey's eldest daughter Linda opens the door for Marta

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: How you doing kiddo. Linda is 60ish, well put together, sharp and steely eyed. She dresses and speaks with just a little more sharpness than any situation she's in requires.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Hi Linda. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Ueuh. The funeral helped. I guess. Just seeing him. I thought you should have been there. I was out voted. Linda's husband Richard walks in, on the phone. Same age Linda, gruff and confident, will put his feet up on anything.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: I'm not the cop so I don't know. Alright fine, don't come, get arrested. Die up your own ass all I care. (hangs up) He's not coming. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICHARD (ON PHONE) (cont'd) (to Marta) Ransom. Little shit. Missed the funeral. STATE TROOPER WAGNER, fresh faced in his 30s, pokes his h in through a door.

dialogues.speaker: TROOPER WAGNER
dialogues.text: Excuse me, we're ready for you now, we'd like to see you one at a time.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Alright I'll go first. I'm assuming this will all be wrapped up before the memorial tonight.

dialogues.speaker: TROOPER WAGNER
dialogues.text: We'll do our best ma'am. Linda exits with Wagner, leaving Richard and Marta.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: So. How you doing kiddo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mystery and horror memorabilia scattered on the shelves. Linda sits opposite three men: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, in his 30s, in a working suit. Very good at his job. The young Trooper Wagner stands behind him. Sitting back behind both of them, almost blending into th background, is a slight man in a linen suit. Legs and arm fold sharply, like a paper crane. Silent, listening.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: We are just going to reintroduce ourselves as a formality, I'm Detective Lieutenant Elliott, and this is Trooper Wagner. Now, I'm going to record, just makes it easier. (squints at his phone) Alright, we're with Linda Drysdale, nee Thrombey, Harlan Thrombey's eldest daughter, in discussing the events the night of his demise, one week ago, November 8th.

dialogues.speaker: TROOPER WAGNER
dialogues.text: We're sorry for your loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dry as chalk) Thank you that means a lot. Elliott checks his notes.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: So we understand that night the family had gathered to celebrate your father's eighty fifth birthday.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: How was that?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: The party? Pre my dad's death? It was great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warmly lit, classic rock playing, food laid out. Linda an Richard mingle happily with the rest of the family (who we'll meet shortly.)

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Did anyone besides the family show face?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Uh. There was Fran, the housekeeper. Marta, Harlan's caregiver, good girl, hard worker. Family's from Ecuador. And Wanetta - Greatnana, Harlan's mom. At the snack table wearing a dozen coats, a woman who mig be three hundred years old. She pounds down chips and dip like a machine.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (wow) His mom? How old is she?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Okay, Your son Ransom, was he there as well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes but he left early. RANSOM DRYSDALE, roguishly handsome in his early 30s, breezes out the side door, past Greatnana.

dialogues.speaker: GREATNANA
dialogues.text: Ransom, are you leaving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The strange man in the linen suit taps a piano key, as if reminding to ask him something.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Right, did all three of you show up at around the same time?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: N...0, Richard came early to help the caterers set up. She raises a questioning finger to ask about the man but

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Okay and you and your husband Richard work for a real estate firm in Boston?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (sharp) It's my company.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: (checks notes) Sorry. Right.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I built my business from the ground up.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Just like your dad. You two were very close?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: We had our own secret way of communicating. You had to find that with dad. You had to find a game to play with him. And if you did that, and played by his rules...  CUT TO: Richard in the chair Linda was in, giving his statement.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Everyone idolizes their dad, right?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: I don't know, do they?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Very much not, don't know why I said that. But Linda does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harlan Thrombey, surrounded by his family, Richard and Li flanking him, a birthday cake with candles. All smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Harlan started with a rusty Smith- Corona, built himself into one of the bestselling mystery writers of all time.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Seems like all his kids are self made overachievers. Richard makes a "...sure" face.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: WALT THROMBEY now sits in the questioning chair. Late 40s softly obsequious in a sweater and loafers. His leg is in cast.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: For the record, I'm speaking to Walt Thrombey, Harlan Thrombey's youngest son. LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT (cont'd) So you run your father's publishing company?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's my - it's our, it's the family's publishing company, dad trusts me to run it. 30 languages, over 80 million copies sold. A real legacy. You guys fans?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT TROOPER WAGNER
dialogues.text: I don't do much fiction - BIG fan. Big. TROOPER WAGNER (cont'd) His plots, like something like "A Thousand Knives," with the - I don't want to spoil it but - the cow and the shotgun, like where do you come up with that?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Dad said the plots just popped into his head fully formed, that was the easy part for him - TAP from the linen suit man's finger.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: You live in town, right? You guys probably arrived at around the same time? Walt looks at Linen suit, thrown.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Uh. We all got here around 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt laughing and mingling with his nervous wife DONNA.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My wife Donna, she's my rock. Richard backs up into Donna, who YELPS in fear and throws her martini in the air. Richard jumps, but Walt doesn't even register it.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Jeeesus! Donna, you alright?

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And my son Jacob, he's sixteen. Very politically active.  10. His angry looking son JACOB, who is always on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick cuts, each in the chair:

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: The boy's literally a Nazi

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: He's an alt-right troll dipshit

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Kids today, with the internet, amazing.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: So the night went well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exact same moment we saw with Richard and Linda of Harlan in front of the birthday cake - but now it's Walt, Donna and Jacob next to Harlan.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I mean. We're all gutted but I'm happy we got that night with him. To be by his side, to think about our books and what we've accomplished with them, it's like I can still feel his hand on my shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Passing the torch. Cut to: JONI THROMBEY in the chair. A striking woman, tal and boho chic in chunky jewelry and a flowy dress.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: So we are with Joni Thrombey, Harlan Thrombey's... daughter in law?

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: Mm. I was married to his son Neil, We had one daughter, Meg, and then Neil passed on fifteen years ago.  11.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: And you remained close to the Thrombeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joni dances with various family members, free and flowing

dialogues.speaker: JONI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Oh they're my family. I feel simultaneously freed by and supported by them, that balance of opposites is the nugget of Flam.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Sorry, the Nugget of?

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: Flam.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Ah! Yeah Flam, right, your skin care company. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: I forgive you, yes, it's skin care but it promotes a total lifestyle. Self sufficiency with an acknowledgment of human need. That's Flam, but it's also Harlan. He got me and Meg through some tough times. Meg in the chair.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Granddad gives my mom a yearly allowance, and he's never missed wiring a tuition payment to my schools. He's a genuinely selfless man.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: You left his party early?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: To see some friends at Smith.  12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meg trots out. Linda, pissed, to Richard so Joni can hear

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: you know, Dad's paying for her crypto-Marxist postdeconstructual feminist poetry theory whatever major, she could have stuck around for the cake.

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: I think Linda was upset. But Harlan understood. Tap.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Right. You two arrived together to the party at the same time? Joni looks at the linen suit man.

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: If I could - pause - because I, who is that guy? And why are we doing all this? Again?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Just some follow up questions, just being thorough, in order to determine the manner of death. Cut back to Walt in the chair.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: (almost laughing) So by "manner of death" you mean if he was killed. If one of us killed him. One of his family?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: None of us think that, this is pro forma, all of it. CUT TO: Richard in the chair. He doesn't buy it.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Ok. So who the fuck is that?  13. He points at linen suit. Elliott takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: This is Benoit Blanc.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (the hell?) Benoit Blanc?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Yes. Mr. Blanc is a private investigator of great renown. Joni in the chair. Linda in the

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: Wait a minute - I read a tweet about a New Yorker article about you. The last of the gentlemen sleuths? You solved that case with the tennis champ - you're famous!

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Mr. Blanc is not with the police department, he is not officially involved with the case but he has offered to consult. I happily obliged and I can vouch for him. chair.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Mr. Blanc, I know who you are, I read your New Yorker profile. It was delightful. I just buried my eighty five year old father who committed suicide. Why are you here? Elliott and Wagner turn back to Blanc, who leans forward slightly and speaks in the gentlest southern lilt you have ever heard in your life.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: I am here at the behest of a client.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: I cannot say, but let me assure you this: my presence will be ornamental. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLANC (cont'd) You will find me a respectful, quiet, passive observer. Of the truth. Elliott and Wagner turn nervously back to Linda. She doesn't look thrilled. Cut to Richard.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Fine. Are we getting there?

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Nearly. Harlan's nurse. She was at the party in a professional capacity? Blanc begins idly playing with a silver dollar.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Marta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family is engaged in an animated discussion, Marta standing on the outskirts.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I guess. Harlan hired her to be around, take care of whatever medical needs pop up, but really she's like part of the family. Richard beckons with his cake, calls Marta into the discussion, into the circle of the family. RICHARD (V.O.) (cont'd) Good kid, been a good friend to Harlan. Her family's from Paraguay. Linda really likes her work ethic.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: “Immigrants - we get the job done." From Hamilton. Wagner gives him a smile to show he got the reference.

dialogues.speaker: TROOPER WAGNER
dialogues.text: Oh Hamilton!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I saw it at the public.  15. Cut to Linda back in the chair.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: May I just - and then I'll recede, but as a self made man myself I have to express my admiration for how you've followed in your father's footsteps.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Just marvelous. The whole family too. Joni with her things, Walt with his publishing empire.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Well. Blanc pauses. Doesn't push anything. Just waits a moment. LINDA (cont'd) Yes. I mean. Walt, yeah. He's done well with what dad's given him. Walt - not like it matters but he was sort of adrift, dad gave him the job, but really dad hands him a book twice a year and Walt publishes it, I mean... it's just not the same.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: But surely Walt runs the merchandising, adaptations, film and television rights... Linda squints, narrowing her eyes on Blanc. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Are you baiting me, Detective? You know he doesn't, and you think I'm dumb enough to be baited into talking family business, into shit talking my brother in front of a police detective and a state trooper - Richard in the chair.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Walt doesn't run shit! There are no film or TV rights, Harlan's never allowed any adaptations of his books. Hates the idea.  16.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Oh yeah! Drives Walt nuts, cause that's where the real money's at. When he gets a little Irish courage in him he'll get into it with Harlan.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Did he get “into it" at the party?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt with a drink in his hand has cornered Harlan. Richar watches across the room as Walt goes from arguing to pleading.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He wouldn't leave him alone, poor guy. Harlan had to give him the hook. Harlan has had enough, he takes Walt's arm and leads him into the drawing room for a private talk. RICHARD (V.O.) (cont'd) I didn't hear what he said but he must have really handed him his lunch, Walt was like a wounded puppy the rest of the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt in the chair, indignant.

dialogues.speaker: WALT BLANC
dialogues.text: What? Richard said what? Jesus. No, we didn't get I'm just trying to get an “into it." accurate impression - Harlan took you aside at the party, when you returned you were chastened, what did Harlan say to you? Walt starts to open his mouth, hesitates. Off his frightened face we FLASH BACK:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt, drunk, Harlan guiding him firmly into the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: WALT HARLAN
dialogues.text: The Netflix guys, their business affairs guy sent over something, hard numbers this time, and I think - this is a window, it's not Walt. going to last and you should just look at these numbers Walt.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Dad you put me in charge of our books let me be in charge, let me do this! Please.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: They're not our books, son. They're my books. And this is not how I wanted to have this conversation but, you're right, it's unfair of me to keep you tethered to something that isn't yours to control.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: I've done you a grave disservice all these years, I've kept you from building something of your own, that's yours. You're not going to run the publishing house anymore. You are free of it.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Dad. Are you firing me?

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: We'll talk about details tomorrow. But my mind's made up. Good boy. Harlan pats his face, then leaves him shell shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to Walt's hesitating face. The briefest of moments h passed. Walt lies:  18.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: We talked, we had a business discussion, about e-books, Jesus, it was nothing. You want to talk about an argument, hell Ransom had an argument with him.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Ransom, Richard and Linda's son?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Look we love Ransom, he is a good kid, we love him.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: -.-but

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: But he's always been the black sheep of the family, and I'm not, I, I keep stuff like this in the family, but with Ransom, he's never had a job. But dad for some unknown reason has always supported him, they've got this love hate bond. They fight. But that night, god. They had a blow out.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family having a conversation, everyone but Harlan, Ja and Ransom. It grinds to a halt as through the door to Harlan's study indistinct shouting booms.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We couldn't make it out, but it was huge. And it was strange they went in another room to do it - they usually love stoking up drama in front of the whole family. Ransom bursts out of the doors and storms out of the part past Greatnana.

dialogues.speaker: GREATNANA
dialogues.text: Ransom are you leaving?  19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard in the chair.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Speaking of getting into it, you were at the house early to help the caterer set up. Did you converse with Harlan at that time?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: He was there, we must have spoke.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: In his study?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: You see, I spoke with the caterer this morning. She didn't see you helping her staff, but she did hear Harlan in a screaming match with someone that afternoon. In his study.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I don't, a screaming match? No. Joni was here too, she was early, maybe it was her, ask her.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: These were two male voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CATERER walks through with a platter. Pauses, hears shouting through the wall.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Harlan shouted the phrase

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: .»..you tell her or I will!

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: You tell her. Or I will. Bells ringing?  20. For a just a split second, Richard considers what he is going to say. In the second, we FLASH BACK:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harlan showing Richard photos on a laptop. Long lens photos, of Richard kissing a woman who is not Linda. Richard glares at it, Harlan turns an old baseball over i his hands.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That's none of your business, Harlan. Stay out of my marriage. Harlan holds up a sealed small envelope with flowery embroidery, "L" written on the front.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: I know my daughter. She'd want to know. I've put it all in this letter to her, tomorrow she gets it.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD HARLAN
dialogues.text: I'm warning you once, don't She deserves to know, you're do this like hell - going to tell her! Harlan slams the baseball down on the desk. HARLAN (cont'd) You tell her or I will!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to Richard. He grins, snaps his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yes. I know - yes, ha. So. Harlan decided to finally put his mom ina nursing home. Which Linda always opposed. And I was going to wait till we were back home in Boston to tell her, so there wouldn't be a whole scene, but Harlan wanted me to tell her then. That was it. Sorry. Forgot. Joni in the chair.

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: The house?  21.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Early. Richard said you were there.

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: I was. At the house early.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: To see Harlan?

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: To see Harlan. Yes. Joni stops, smelling something in the air. She's about to ask about it but -

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: What were you seeing Harlan about?

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: It was just a mix up with the payment for Meg's tuition.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to press, what kind of mix up? Joni hesitates, we FLASH BACK:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harlan at his desk, toying with the same old baseball. Th is a thing he does at his desk. Joni standing, arms cross

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: The school hasn't got the check yet, I don't know why Alan didn't mail it

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Alan didn't mail it because he caught a discrepancy. Alan's office has been wiring tuition directly to the school, as per your request. But Phyllis's office that handles your yearly allowance has been wiring the tuition money directly to you as well. As per your request. You've been double dipping Meg's tuition, stealing from me. A hundred thousand dollars a year. For the past four years.  22. Harlan shows Joni a letter from his business manager, wit transaction receipts attached.

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: Harlan. I don't know how this mix up happened but Harlan opens his ledger, hand writes a check.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: I'm writing this tuition check, then that is the last money you or Meg will get from me.

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: Please you don't understand

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: I know it'1l hurt but it's for the best. Joni's speechless, her face frozen. Harlan puts the baseball down and detaches the check, holds it out to her HARLAN (cont'd) My mind's made up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to Joni. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: Just a money wiring issue. With the office at the school. So I had to ask Harlan to cut a check for this semester. No big deal.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Why don't we take a breather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joni comes out into the foyer from the library, obviously rattled. She pulls it together quick when Linda comes dow the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Joni. You haven't seen Richard have you?  23.

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: No, I was just in with the - no.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Richard! Alone, Richard waits very still for Linda's footsteps to walk away, then when he knows she's not coming in he furtively rifles through desk drawers, finding various ridiculous ephemera. He finds a small locked drawer, jimmies it open with a letter opener. Inside - the small pink envelope Harlan threatened him wi in his flashback. He rips it open, pulls out the card inside. It is blank. Richard almost laughs. Drops it onto the desk.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch. He spots Harlan's old baseball. Grabs it, spitefully chuc it out the open window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blanc, Elliott and Wagner stroll long the wide lawn besid the house. Blanc ignites a long thin cigar.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm a victim of my own expectations. But when the great Benoit Blanc knocks on my door, I expect it's going to be for something... if not extraordinary, at least interesting. This is an open and shut case of suicide. (checks watch) And Benny we're at the point where I need to know what we're doing here. Blanc notices the OLD BASEBALL lying in the grass. He pic it up idly.  24.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: The method, throat slit. Typical of a suicide?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Dramatic. But look around. The guy practically lives in a CLUE board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marta sits alone, across from a portrait of Harlan. Muffl voices out on the patio. Cigar smoke drifts by outside. She creeps over to the glass door. Puts her ear to it.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You ask me to drag all these good people back for questioning, go over it all again, I don't get it. This is a pleasant family with the usual quarrels but no possible motives for murder - where are you going? At that moment, BLANC's face appears right next to Marta' staring right at her through the distorted glass. She yel and falls back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blanc opens the glass door. Marta steps back sheepishly, but with a warm nod Blanc beckons for her to join them.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Harlan Thrombey's nurse, Marta...

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: ...Cabrera

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Marta Cabrera.

dialogues.speaker: TROOPER WAGNER
dialogues.text: Miss Cabrera, you can just wait inside - we'll be with you soon.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Miss Cabrera, I been doing a little poking, you're hired on a part time basis as a registered nurse, yes?  25.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I don't work for a VNA. Harlan hired me directly.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: You're paid a flat rate for how many hours a week?

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: I started at 15, but slowly he... needed more help.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Medical help?

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: He needed a friend. Blanc smiles at the girl, genuinely touched.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Does having a kind heart make you a good nurse?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Blanc.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Yes. Marta we were just discussing possible motives in the family. I suspect Harlan has told you much unfiltered truth about each of them, and a little bird has told me, how shall I put this delicately? You have a regurgitive reaction to mistruthin'.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Yes. It's something that I have had as a kid. It's a physically thing that I - I - Just the thought of lying, yeah, it makes me puke.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Really? Is Richard having an affair? Marta is stunned. She FLASHES BACK TO:  26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reads, Harlan sits at his laptop, heavy with sadness.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Why do men instinctively pull at loose threads on their parachutes?

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: What? Harlan spins his laptop towards her - the Richard photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to our scene. Marta looks queasy, tries to stall.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Heh - Richard? - affair? Heh.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: A yes or no will do. She struggles, her jaw clenched, face working hard, then attempts -

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: sees no And immediately VOMITS into a nearby planter.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT TROOPER WAGNER
dialogues.text: Whoa! Oh my god! They all rush to her, Blanc brings water, awfully concern

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Dear girl I'm sorry. I assumed you were speaking figuratively. Blanc takes the shortest acceptable beat of concern befor turning to Elliott. BLANC (cont'd) Quite something. But I was obviously right, Richard is having an affair, his father in law found out and confronted him. "You tell her. Or I will."

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Even if it's true... you ok?  27. Marta gives a weak thumbs up, recovering

dialogues.speaker: ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Even if that was right, protecting his marriage is weak sauce as a motive.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Well. And then there is... Joni.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT TROOPER WAGNER
dialogues.text: Joni? Joni?! TROOPER WAGNER (cont'd) Lifestyle guru Joni? No. Harlan was supporting her and her daughter, she had the opposite of a motive. Marta tries to quietly slip back into the house

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: And if that support was threatened? Miss Cabrera one moment please

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: I'm just going to go get some Scope

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Miss Cabrera, was Harlan planning on cutting off Joni's allowance? Off Marta's "oh god no" face:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harlan looking at the letter from his business manager, w the transaction receipts. He sighs heavily.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Oh, Joni.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: What's up? He hands her the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marta's face works against impending nausea.  28.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Ok don't answer that if you're going to puke. Please. But Blanc presses.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Meg said Harlan pays the school directly, Joni says he sends the money to her. Both were true, she was pocketing the double payment, Harlan found out and cut her off without a cent. Yes? Marta starts to shake her head no, but her throat convuls She nods. Blanc hands her a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: TROOPER WAGNER
dialogues.text: And she bumps him off for the inheritance? Come. On! Have you seen her insta? She's an influencer.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: An allowance as a motive, Blanc. She has her business. More weak sauce. Blanc idly scratches a spot on the side of his neck.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Granted. But she lied. To me. All three of them did.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Three?

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Walter.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: I see where you are going with this.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: But there was something else. Harlan had turned Walter down before regarding film rights, but that night something Harlan said shook him. We look at the pattern, Harlan was cleaning house. I wonder... (to Marta) did he plan to fire Walter?  29.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: (honest & relieved) Can I wait inside? I don't feel like I should be here.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Yes, please just wait inside but stay close. She steps back in, grateful. Blanc to Elliott:

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: You've been very patient my friend, and you are right, none of these weak alibis and domestic squibbles answer your question: why is Benoit Blanc here? But now I will tell you why. (beat) I am here because this morning someone dodged one very important question.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Me. Linda asked who hired me.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: So who hired you?

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: I. Do. Not. Know. An envelope of cash showed up at my apartment yesterday, with the news clipping of Thrombey's death.

dialogues.speaker: TROOPER WAGNER
dialogues.text: An envelope? That worked?

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: An envelope of cash. Blanc indicates with his fingers - several inches thick. BLANC (cont'd) So somebody suspects foul play, but goes through this ha cha dance of hiring me, of staying anonymous. It makes no damn sense. Compels me though. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLANC (cont'd) (beat) Walk me through everyone's whereabouts at the time of death. Elliott hesitates, but Blanc's got him hooked. He flips open his notebook. Blanc leans back, closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: We know, the party broke up at 11:30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marta and Harlan vanish up the stairs towards the third floor, while Richard and Linda head into the bedroom righ next to the stairs. Down the hallway Joni waves, and duck into another bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Marta took Harlan upstairs to give him his meds, Richard and Linda and Joni went right to bed. Now we do have this: the stairs leading up to Harlan's bedroom and his attic office creak horribly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard sleeps deep, Linda sleeps lightly.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And Linda is a light sleeper. So we know every time someone took the stairs that night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joni has decorated the room with colorful silks and candl She is in lotus position on her bed, meditating.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The first was when Joni heard a ka- THUNK from somewhere above her in the house. Ka-THUNK! Joni looks up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joni trots down the hall and up the creaky stairs.  31.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She's concerned about Harlan, she went up to investigate. Waking Linda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CREAK CREAK CREAK! From outside. Linda's eyes pop open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joni knocks on the door of Harlan's attic office. It open and Harlan answers. In the room behind him we see Marta, her back turned, preparing a hypo needle.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Harlan was in his attic office with Marta. He explained that they had just knocked the GO board over - that game with the grid and stones, they play it every night, and he was fine, go to bed. So she does. The spilled GO board on the floor. Joni kisses Harlan on the cheek, goes. He shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda has just gotten back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ten minutes later, Linda is woken a second time, by Marta leaving. CREAK CREAK CREAK! Linda wakes, supremely annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Walt! I'm leaving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt and Jacob sit on the porch, Walt with a cigar, Jacob with his phone. Marta trots through, saying goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Walt was smoking a cigar on the porch with his son. He saw her leave and drive off, and noted the time - midnight.  32. Walt glances at his watch. Midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda with a pillow over her head.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Fifteen minutes later, Linda is woken for the third and final time. By someone coming down the stairs. CREAK CREAK CREAK! Linda wakes. You've gotta be kidding m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt, still smoking with Jacob, spots Harlan through the glazed glass, coming down the stairs in the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Harlan. Who came down for midnight snacks, which Walt tried to discourage.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Dad, go to bed! Through the glazed glass, Harlan goes back up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Based on this, the medical examiner determined time of death to be between 12:15 and 2am. As Walt was finishing his cigar, about 12:30, Meg came home. She went straight to bed. Walt and Jacob turned in shortly after that. Meg pulls up, trots past Walt and Jacob and inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meg stirs, wakes. Joni is asleep.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sometime later that night, undetermined but possibly near 3am, Meg woke up because the dogs were barking outside. She used the bathroom and went back to bed.  33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elliott snaps the notebook closed.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: And that's it. Everyone's stories matched, every movement accounted for.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: There is no other staircase up to Harlan's room? Blanc scratches that same spot on the side of his neck.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: No. Just the creaky one. Blanc seems intrigued by this.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Interesting.

dialogues.speaker: TROOPER WAGNER
dialogues.text: So I guess we can rule out Ransom, he wasn't there. And Marta, Harlan was alive after she left. But Meg got home during the time of death window.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: Except it was a suicide. Harlan hit both carotids, we saw from the blood blood splat patterns that they were uninterrupted. Meaning, It's almost impossible for anyone to have been around him at the time. He's the one that cut his own throat. I don't know why we keep going over this.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Physical evidence can tell a clear story with a forked tongue.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT ELLIOTT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: And as we've seen this morning, everyone can lie. Well. Almost everyone.  34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marta in the chair. She shifts, uncomfortable. Blanc, Elliott and Wagner in their normal places.

dialogues.speaker: BLANC
dialogues.text: Ms. Cabrera, we've kept you waiting all afternoon because I wanted to hear from you last. I wanted to have the entire picture of the evening in my head. Your piece of it is at its very center. So please, take your time. You took Mr. Thrombey upstairs at 11:30. And left at midnight. Think very carefully. And with as much detail as possible, tell us what happened in that half hour. Marta is very still. A moment of silence. Blanc flips his silver dollar into the air. She does not say a word, but in that moment while the coi hangs in the air we FLASH BACK with her to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night of the party. A clock on a nightstand: 11:32. Off screen we hear Marta leading Harlan up the creaky stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA HARLAN
dialogues.text: Up up up up - you got it? I got it. Up up up I got it. Marta enters the room, and behind her we see Harlan keep climbing up the narrow stairs to his office.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Up up nooooo no not tonight, no straight to bed tonight it is soooo late c'mon. Harlan. Harlan! She grabs a med kit from the bedroom and follows him, exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harlan sits, setting up a GO board. Marta enters.  35.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA HARLAN
dialogues.text: It's late, I had champagne It's my birthday, we are - no no no You had one glass - we're not breaking tradition on my birthday. Marta puts two vials and a pill box on the GO board. She pulls out two plastic wrapped hypodermics.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Take your goddamn medicine and go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: If you're going to put that vile shit in me you will have to earn it. On my birthday. (playing it up) Eighty fifth. So old. Soo olddd

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Alright old man. 8x8 game. You ready? She sits and they start clacking white and black stones o the board.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN MARTA
dialogues.text: Why can't I beat you at this game? Because I'm not playing to beat you, I'm playing to Oh uh huh. build a beautiful pattern. They play fast, and Marta is obviously winning.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Elder abuse. I'm calling the AARP.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Don't make me get the belt.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: It's basically over. My only hope is that an earthquake will strike. But what are the chances - Harlan starts shaking the table with his knee. He looks around, startled. Marta just stares at him, deadpan. HARLAN (cont'd) Get under a door frame!  36. He tips the whole table and the GO board and med vials an syringe and med kit fall to the soft rug. Things spill ou of the kit. A mess. Marta just shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Meds then beds.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Fair. She retrieves the vials and loads a syringe from one of them. Harlan rolls up his sleeve revealing a pre-inserted catheter. He crosses to close the room's only small windo HARLAN (cont'd) Ugh, Walt's smoking a cigar on the porch. Nasty things.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: How was tonight? She hooks the syringe up to the catheter and slowly injec him bit by bit while he talks.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Tonight was... good.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Because I know you weren't looking forward to it.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: No. But I did it. Cut the line on all four of them. It was not easy. This goddamn fortune. Sometimes I think, everything I've given my family, I've done, maybe without knowing it, maybe, to keep them beneath me. I should have what... maybe, I don't know. Encouraged Walt to write his own stories, not just be a caretaker of mine. Like you said I should. Been a father, not just a provider, to Joni. Like you've also said. I should have been kinder to Linda. And Ransom. Harlan takes a curved ornamental dagger from a display mount, turns it over in his hands. HARLAN (cont'd) Jesus there's so much me in that kid. Confident, stupid, I dunno. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARLAN (cont'd) Protected. Playing life like a game without consequence, till you can't tell the difference between a stage prop and a real knife. He stabs it into the desk, sharp and real. Leaves it ther HARLAN (cont'd) I don't fear death. But god I'd like to fix some of this before I go. Close the book with a flourish. I guess we'll see.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: I guess we will. Hey. Old man. You've had a long day. Wanna do drugs. She loads the second syringe from the second vial.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: you mean the good stuff?

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Yeah but just a tiny bit.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Send me to lala land. Why did I wait till my mid eighties to become a morphine user, what a schmuck, what a nud-nig, this stuff's the best. She pulls the needle from the second vial... then sees th label. Freezes. Blinks at it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Oh my god. She snatches up the first vial she just injected him from Compares the label to the one she just picked up. They're similar but not the same.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Is there a problem?

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: This is what I just gave you 100 milligrams of. But I messed up.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: You gave me 100 milligrams of the good stuff.  38. She immediately pulls an EMERGENCY KIT from a nearby shel starts calmly but quickly going through its contents. HARLAN (cont'd) What's the good stuff dosage supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Lets not call it that right now - three milligrams.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: That's much less. So what happens?

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: I give you an emergency shot of Naloxone, so that you don't die in ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Well no pressure. You know that's an interesting, efficient method for murder, I need to write that down. He gets a little notebook and scribbles while she checks rechecks the kit contents with increasing urgency. HARLAN (cont'd) So if someone switched the meds on purpose I'd be dead in ten minutes, like stone cold dead?

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: You'll feel symptoms in five. Sweats, disorientation. Then yeah, that big a dose, injected, within ten your respiratory - your - yes ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: From the time of injection, so eightish now. And even if the victim called an ambulance when he first felt symptoms, if he was at a country home like this one... where the ambulance takes fifteen minutes to arrive, it would be too late. If the victim didn't have this emergency Naxostuff. He watches her. She's now digging around the carpet, looking under the couch. She dumps the entire contents of the kit out and is now frantically going through it. A be of sweat rolls down Harlan's brow.  39. HARLAN (cont'd) Marta. Do you have Naxostuff?

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Yes! Naloxone yes it comes with the emergency kit - it should be here, it's - fuck. No Harlan it's not here. It's not. Oh my god. They look at each other for a second. She's panicked. He' thinking. MARTA (cont'd) Where's my phone? Shit - She picks up a landline phone on the table, dials 911 wit shaking hands - Before it can even ring, the line goes dead. She looks, unbelieving: Harlan's finger is on the cradle. His eyes are locked with hers, serious and certain. MARTA (cont'd) Harlan what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Marta, listen to me.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA HARLAN
dialogues.text: Harlan we need to - are you Stop. Stop stop, Marta crazy, we need to call, they listen there isn't time stop need to get here I need to - now stop She goes for her cell phone across the room and Harlan st her - they trip and fall to the ground with a KA-THUNK.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA HARLAN
dialogues.text: What are you doing are you Marta it's too late it is nuts? over, it's too late I am dead listen. LISTEN. He actually puts his hand over her mouth. HARLAN (cont'd) Listen. If what you said is true I am gone, there's no saving me, we have six minutes. There is one last thing I need to do in this world, and only you can help me do it. But you need to trust me and do everything I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Get you out of this. Think of your mom - please trust me, we have to 40. make this look ironclad like it can't have been your fault. You. Can't. Have done this.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: My mom...? CREAK on the stairs outside.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Get up. A knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: JONI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Harlan? Marta? Everything alright? Harlan and Marta stand. She's dazed, deer in the headlights, but he's focused and sharp. He turns from the door.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Stand here, keep your back to me, don't say a word. Harlan opens the door. While he gets rid of Joni with Marta, who stands stock still, tears running face, eyes wild - what does she do? HARLAN (cont'd) Joni.

dialogues.speaker: JONI
dialogues.text: I - hi - I heard something, is everything ok?

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN
dialogues.text: Oh yes we just, I just knocked over the GO board, sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: JONI
